thread.title: Inside Sea-Tac's newest elite lounge aimed at tech, international travelers
thread.title_full: Inside Sea-Tac's newest elite lounge aimed at tech, international travelers

author: Steve Wilhelm
title: Inside Sea-Tac's newest elite lounge aimed at tech, international travelers
text:
See All Homes of the Day “The reason is we have a lot of international flights, a lot of full-fare passengers out of here, because of the tech companies,” said Steve Danishek, president of Seattle-based travel consultancy TMA Inc. “It’s simply a way of incentivizing American Express cardholders to spend more money to get the status to get in the door.” Such lounges provide a respite from the more hectic aspects of 21st century airport life, into a serene club-like atmosphere with snacks and drinks. “The Centurion Studio offers its members numerous amenities including comfortable seating, charging stations, free high-speed Wi-Fi, and Seattle-inspired light bites, wine, beer and artisanal beverages,” said a release from the company. The new lounge is in fact the seventh at Sea-Tac, but unique in that it’s offered by a credit card company and not by an airline or by the airport itself. Four of the lounges within Sea-Tac are operated by airlines: United, British Airways , Delta and Alaska. Reflecting the battle for passengers between the latter two, Delta’s 8,000-square-foot lounge, built on the roof of the South Satellite in 2012, is the largest at Sea-Tac, said port spokesman Perry Cooper . The Atlanta carrier opened it as an expansion from its earlier 6,800-square-foot facility, as it also expanded its flights into Sea-Tac. But competitor Alaska also is expanding its lounge footprint, and currently operates two: one on Concourse B, and a temporary lounge in the North Satellite. Alaska plans a larger lounge there, Cooper said. The port also operates two lounges of its own, called the Club at SEA, which enable international carriers to provide lounge facilities. The larger meaning of the seventh lounge, Centurion Studio, is competition, Danishek said., “A lot of business travelers are very competitive people, and they like one-upping each other,” he said. “That’s where the competition is now, to get the big spenders on your airline, or using their card.”
